title: Machine Learning Summer Schools
segmentation: I'm happy to report on the Machine learning summer schools, so in particular about the last one which.
Happened and tubing and August 2007 that was jointly organized, everything burner true.

Quite quite long history already, so this was the 9th machine Learning Summer School.
The first one was in Canberra in 2002 and this was 2007, the 9th one and.

So most people are coming from Germany, which is not too surprising because it was happening in Germany but also from France and United Kingdom.
Quite a few people, and also from yes, actually quite a few people came.
OK.
So we.
We had about 10% undergraduates.
We had quite.
I mean most.
Most of the participants were PhD students, so quite a few of them were at the beginning of their PhD, so it was still very good today.

So I mean we try to get more undergraduates in there, but they were not so many applications, so we had 6 interest industrial participants and professors which we which we accepted by default and nine postdocs.
And we were giving trouble grants to people who seem to need it.
So at 10,000 euros in travel brands.
OK, so we had three different things we had lectures or we had a practical courses and we had evening talks.
So the main part was of course lectures.
There are between 4:00 and eight hours long.

And here's a list we try to combine application courses, basic courses and I mean let's say courses on statistical learning theory, something on Bayesian methods, something on kernels, and then Additionally maybe something on optimization and then.
Some applications like.
Topics in image and video processing, and I talk for instance on bioinformatics.
OK, so.
Are there questions for this so?
I mean OK.
So it's quite quite a long list of full course, so compared to other summer schools that lost it, at least got quite a bit longer.
So practical courses that was for two hours.
Every participant could take two practical courses, so this was a limit.
I mean the capacity limit.

So we allowed at most 25 people per course, and like everybody, I think two people were sharing a computer and doing some tasks like a programming task where I mean so like under supervision of one of the supervisors like Joaquin, Kiniro Candela, Emmanuel TV.
When he assigned looks both my TCG by T. So people really liked these kind of practical courses in the Summer School 2003, so there we had only three in the feedback we got, like.
I mean, we got told me to increase the number for the practical courses, so we increased it to five, but it's a lot of work of preparing these affecting horses.
But people like to begin and told us we should do more.
End.
We also had a few evening speakers.

That was interesting.

So and I think they succeeded for school.

So it was like maybe 8 hours, sometimes 9.
So I mean they didn't have a practical courses every day.
So, and even on Saturday, so we really filled it up two weeks.
And yeah, I mean maybe the last days you could see it was maybe a bit too much, but.
So I think people still liked it.
So it wasn't even more than the summer schools.
For instance in 2002, and we had there, we had much fewer courses.
Fewer long, long courses and more shorter courses.
I think I like the structure as it is now and also intrusion.
Three, we had very few along courses and then just much more short courses.
Um?
So, but the structure is similar to the to the summer school into being 2003.
We had the long courses, short courses, practical sessions, and in the evening talks and we actually had one day where students could give talks as well.
So we had 13 talks by students.
I think on one end of the first week.
OK, so.

Yeah, I think it was essentially all very positive.
So people asked for more practical courses and.

Thank you.

Syllabus for a summer school?

So I guess that could help these kind of summer schools to really concentrate mainly on the PhD part, where I mean really show.

I don't know so.

What should be taught could be useful.

So and I mean the topics were varying overtime.

But yeah, I like the last.

So I mean.

The kind of standard as the students evolve through time, yes.

I agree, I agree.
